SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

traer.physics
Interface Force

All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractForce, Attraction, Spring, TargettedForce, TwoBodyForce, UniversalForce
public interface Force

This interface specifies the basic mechanics of a Force.

There are two basic skeletal implementations: a TargettedForce with specified targets, where the apply() method is used; and a UniversalForce that is applied to a Particle, where the apply(Particle) method is used.

The Spring force between two Particles is an example of the first form, while the universal free-fall Gravity is an example of the second form.

An intermediate skeletal implementation of this interface is provided in the AbstractForce class. Unless substantial extra behavior associated with turning a Force on and off needs to be specified, in general users should extend the AbstractForce class instead of implementing this interface.

Since:
January 2008
Author:
Jeffrey Traer Bernstein, Carl Pearson

Method Summary
 Force apply()
          Applies this Force.
 Particle apply(Particle p)
          Applies this Force to a Particle p.
 boolean isOff()
          Returns true if this force is off.
 boolean isOn()
          Returns true if this force is on.
 Force turnOff()
          Turns the Force off; after calling this method, calls to isOff() will return true.
 Force turnOn()
          Turns the Force on; after calling this method, calls to isOn() will return true.
 Force turnOn(boolean on)
          Sets the Force to the argument on.
 

Method Detail

turnOff

Force turnOff()
Turns the Force off; after calling this method, calls to isOff() will return true. Implementations of the Force interface should delegate this call to the turnOn(boolean) method, with a false argument.

Returns:
this Force, de-activated

turnOn

Force turnOn()
Turns the Force on; after calling this method, calls to isOn() will return true. Implementations of the Force interface should delegate this call to the turnOn(boolean) method, with a true argument.

Returns:
this Force, activated

turnOn

Force turnOn(boolean on)
Sets the Force to the argument on. Subsequent calls to isOn() will return the value of on. Implementations of the Force interface should delegate turnOff() and turnOn() to this method.

Parameters:
on - the state to set the Force in.
Returns:
this Force, with appropriate activation condition

isOn

boolean isOn()
Returns true if this force is on. Will also consistently return !isOff(). Implementations of the Force interface should delegate the behavior of one of these methods to the other, to ensure consistency.

Returns:
true if this force is on

isOff

boolean isOff()
Returns true if this force is off. Will also consistently return !isOn(). Implementations of the Force interface should delegate the behavior of one of these methods to the other, to ensure consistency.

Returns:
true if this force is off

apply

Force apply()
            throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException,
                   java.lang.IllegalStateException
Applies this Force.

Returns:
this Force
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the implementing class uses apply(Particle) instead.
java.lang.IllegalStateException - optionally, if the Force is currently off

apply

Particle apply(Particle p)
               throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException,
                      java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                      java.lang.NullPointerException
Applies this Force to a Particle p. Must be specified by implementing classes.

Parameters:
p - the Particle to apply the Force to; may not be null
Returns:
the Particle p, after the Force is applied.
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the implementing class uses apply() instead.
java.lang.IllegalStateException - optionally, if the Force is currently off, or if the Particle is fixed
java.lang.NullPointerException - if p == null
